title-group.article-title: Investigating the effect of geometrical parameters on distortions in butt-welded plates

contrib-group.aff: University of Applied Science and Technology, Tehran, Iran

author-notes.corresp: Mahsa Seyyedian Choobi, Iranian Welding Research and Engineering Center, University of Applied Science and Technology, Tehran 1455973585, Iran. Email: mseyyedian@yahoo.com

abstract.p: Welding-induced distortions are one of the major problems frequently encountered in industry. Different geometrical and welding process parameters are believed to influence distortions. One of the most common types of distortions frequently observed in butt-welded plates is angular distortion. In this study, the effect of geometrical parameters on angular distortions in butt-welded plates has been investigated numerically and experimentally. A comprehensive study has been performed, and several cases with different plate lengths, widths and thicknesses have been studied. Distortions have been predicted by three-dimensional thermo-elastic-plastic finite element simulation. The finite element results have been verified by a series of experimental measurements for temperatures and angular distortions. The results of this study revealed that plate thickness, length and width influence the magnitude and mode of distortions greatly. The results revealed that decreasing the plate thickness or increasing the weld length results in higher and nonlinear angular distortions. Increasing the plate width has an adverse effect and reduces the angular distortion. In addition, the thickness of the plate has a key role on distortion behavior and can lead to buckling in thin plates.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Distortions due to welding are one of the major problems frequently encountered in industry. The tendency to out-of-plane distortions results in fabrication penalties such as poor fit-up and poor buckling performance, which usually requires expensive rework. The issue of welding distortions has already been discussed by many researchers. For example, Camilleri and Gray,1 Dhingra and Murphy2 and Long et al.3 investigated welding-induced angular distortions in butt-welded plates using both finite element method and experimental measurements. Deng and Murakawa,4 Deng,5 Camilleri et al.6 and Bachorski et al.7 predicted welding angular distortions in carbon steel butt-welded plates using finite element method. Tsai et al.,8 Deng et al.9,10 and Teng et al.11 predicted angular distortions in T-joint fillet welds using finite element method. The issue of buckling distortion in thin panels was discussed by Michaleris and DeBiccari,12 Michaleris and Sun,13 Deo and Michaleris14 and Deng and Murakawa.15 Many welding process parameters and joint details are believed to influence distortions.16 Deng and Murakawa15 investigated the effect of certain welding parameters such as welding procedure, heat input, welding sequence and thickness on buckling distortions in large T-joint panels. Mollicone et al.17 investigated the effect of tack welds and clamping conditions on out-of-plane distortions in butt-welded plates. Seyyedian Choobi et al.18 investigated the effect of welding speed on angular distortions in butt-welded plates. Seyyedian Choobi et al.19 and Deng et al.20 investigated the effect of welding sequence on angular distortions. Murugan and Gunaraj21 examined the effect of number of passes and wire feed rate in gas metal arc welding (GMAW) process on angular distortions in multi-pass butt-welded plates.

A literature review revealed that in spite of all the researches in the field of welding distortions, the issue of angular distortion behavior as a function of different parameters has not been studied yet. Since angular distortion is one of the most important types of distortions commonly observed in butt-welded plates, this study focused on angular distortions, and the effect of geometrical parameters on angular distortion behavior has been investigated in detail For this purpose, 304 stainless steel plates with different dimensions have been selected and single-pass butt welded by gas tungsten arc welding (GTAW) method. Distortions have been predicted by three-dimensional finite element simulation using ANSYS 10.22 Simulations have been performed for a wide range of dimensions including thicknesses of 1, 1.5 and 2 mm, lengths of 100–350 mm and widths of 100–400 mm. Totally, 41 different cases have been analyzed. In order to verify the numerical results, six experiments have been carried out and temperature histories and angular distortions have been measured.

sec.title: Finite element simulation
sec.p: Three-dimensional finite element simulation of welding has been performed by an uncoupled thermo-mechanical analysis. For this purpose, a nonlinear transient thermal analysis has been performed first. Then, a nonlinear elasto-plastic mechanical analysis has been conducted using temperature results as thermal loads. The three-dimensional finite element model used in this simulation is shown in Figure 1. Considering the symmetry condition, only one-half of the welded plate was considered as the finite element model. The finite element model used for both thermal and mechanical analyses was the same except the element type. In the thermal analysis, eight-node brick elements with temperature degree of freedom at each node (SOLID70) were used. In the structural analysis, eight-node brick elements with three translational degrees of freedom at each node (SOLID45) were used. Because of high temperature gradients in and around the fusion zone (FZ) and heat-affected zone (HAZ), a relatively fine mesh was used within a distance of 10 mm from the weld centerline. According to the mesh sensitivity analysis, the smallest element size was considered 1 × 1 × 1 mm. Away from the HAZ, the element sizes increased with the increase of distance from the weld centerline. In order to model the addition of filler material element, birth and death technique was used in the simulation. In this technique, all elements including those to be born in the later stages of the analysis were created first. Then, the weld elements were deactivated by multiplying their stiffness by a severe reduction factor. In the thermal analysis, deactivated elements were reactivated sequentially when they came under the influence of welding heat source. In the subsequent structural analysis, deactivated elements were reactivated at the solidification temperature. Melting and ambient temperatures were considered as reference temperatures for thermal expansion coefficients of filler and base metal, respectively.

In order to apply thermal boundary conditions, convective heat transfer with heat transfer coefficient of 15 × 10−6 W/mm2°C11 and radiative heat transfer with emissivity of 0.5123 were applied to all free surfaces, except the symmetry plane. The symmetry plane was considered adiabatic. The effect of heat transfer due to convection stirring in the molten weld pool was modeled by considering the thermal conductivity much higher than its value at room temperature for temperatures above the melting point. Material properties for both weld and base metal were considered temperature dependent and were taken from Deng and Murakawa.24 Latent heat was considered 260 J/g between solidus temperature of 1424 °C and liquidus temperature of 1454 °C.25 Ambient temperature was assumed 20 °C.

sec.title: Mechanical analysis
sec.p: Mechanical analysis was performed considering rate-independent plasticity model, von Mises yield criterion and bilinear kinematic hardening. The mechanical analysis was conducted using temperature histories obtained from the thermal analysis as thermal body loads. Mechanical boundary conditions were taken from experimental observations. The weld start and stop positions were fixed in the direction perpendicular to the plates surface. The symmetry plane was fixed in the direction perpendicular to weld line. Other mechanical boundary conditions were applied to avoid rigid body motion of the plate.

sec.title: Experimental
sec.p: In order to verify the finite element results, experiments have been performed and temperature histories and angular distortions have been measured. For this purpose, 304 stainless steel plates of dimensions 150 × 200 × 2 and 140 × 150 × 2 mm were single-pass butt welded by GTAW method. The plates had a square-butt groove with zero gap between parts. The plates were tack welded at both ends first and then welded in unrestrained condition. Welding was performed using welding current 96 A, voltage 10 V and welding speed 2.5 mm/s. Experiments were repeated three times for each dimension, and totally six cases were examined.

sec.title: Temperature measurements
sec.p: In order to measure temperature histories, two thermocouples of type K were attached to the top surface of the plates at 10 and 20 mm distances from the weld centerline, along the mid-section of the plate (Figure 2). Welding setup was chosen in a way that most parts of the top and bottom surfaces of the plate were exposed to ambient temperature. The thermocouples were insulated using special insulating ceramics. The thermocouples joints were protected from heat due to arc radiations.

caption.p: Welded plate with thermocouples and deflection measurement points.

sec.title: Angular distortion measurements
sec.p: In order to measure angular distortions, the surface of the plates was marked in equal distances before welding. Deflections were measured at cross point of the lines before welding and after cooling to ambient temperature using a mechanical dial gage. The net deflections were obtained by subtracting the deflections measured before welding from their corresponding values after welding. Then, the angular distortions were calculated as the slope of horizontal lines crossing the measuring points.

sec.title: Comparison of finite element results with experimental measurements
sec.p: Comparison of numerical and experimental temperature histories for the two measuring points at 10 and 20 mm distances from the weld centerline for the two cases with dimensions 150 × 200 × 2 and 140 × 150 × 2 mm are shown in Figures 3 and 4, respectively. An overall good agreement is observed between the numerical and experimental results. The minor difference between the numerical and experimental cooling rates in the second and third experiments shown in Figure 4 is due to the minor deviation of numerical cooling condition from the actual experimental condition.

sec.title: Results of parametric study
sec.p: In this section, a comprehensive parametric study has been performed and the effect of plate thickness, length and width on angular distortions has been investigated. For this purpose, a wide range of dimensions, that is, thicknesses of 1, 1.5, 2 and 3 mm, lengths of 100–350 mm and widths of 100–400 mm have been studied. Totally, 41 different cases have been analyzed.

sec.title: Effect of plate thickness
sec.p: In order to investigate the effect of plate thickness on angular distortions, four cases with thicknesses of 1, 1.5, 2 and 3 mm were studied. Welding conditions for different thicknesses are presented in Table 2. It should be mentioned that in spite of the increase of heat input and weld volume with the increase of thickness, the heat input per unit volume has been kept constant in all cases. The temperature histories of a point at 10 mm distance from the weld centerline for different thicknesses are shown in Figure 7. The results show that decreasing the plate thickness increases cooling rate. The angular distortions at the weld start edge and middle of the weld line for different thicknesses are shown in Figures 8 and 9, respectively. The results show that decreasing the plate thickness increases angular distortions and vertical displacements. Comparison of angular distortions at the edge of the plate for different thicknesses shows that the vertical displacement at the edge of the plate 2 mm is two times more than the vertical displacement of the plate 3 mm. In a similar manner, the vertical displacement at the edge of the plate 1 mm is three times more than the vertical displacement of the plate 3 mm. This is because decreasing the plate thickness decreases its stiffness. Since the stiffness of a body is adversely related to its deformation, decreasing the plate stiffness leads to higher angular distortions. Moreover, uniform through thickness temperature gradients in thin plates results in higher transverse contraction forces in comparison to thick plates. Increase of transverse contraction forces as the primary driver of angular distortion increases consequently angular distortions. Thus, a combination of higher transverse contraction forces, lower stiffness and higher cooling rate in thin plates lead to higher angular distortions in comparison to thick plates.

sec.p: The angular distortions at the weld start edge of the plate and middle of the weld line for different thicknesses show that decreasing the plate thickness from 2 to 1.5 and 1 mm not only increases the angular distortions but also induces nonlinear angular distortions. The angular distortion behavior is linear in plates with thickness 2 and 3 mm, whereas it is nonlinear in plates 1.5 and 1 mm.

sec.title: Effect of plate length
sec.p: In order to investigate the effect of plate length (dimension parallel to the weld line) on angular distortions, a series of different cases with different plate lengths have been studied. The angular distortions at the weld start edge and middle of the weld line for the cases with plate thickness of 1 mm, lengths of 100, 150 and 200 mm and width of 150 mm are shown in Figures 10 and 11, respectively. The results show that increasing the plate length (weld length) increases angular distortions and vertical displacements. The results also reveal that the angular distortion behavior is nonlinear in all cases.

caption.p: Deflections at the weld start edge of the plate for different plate lengths (W= 150 mm).
Deflections at the middle of the weld line for different plate lengths (W= 150 mm).

sec.p: The angular distortions at the weld start edge and middle of the weld line for the cases with plate lengths of 100, 200 and 300 mm and width of 200 mm are presented in Figures 12 and 13, respectively. The results show that for the cases with plate lengths of 100 and 200 mm, increasing the plate length increases the angular distortions. But, for the case with plate length of 300 mm, the angular distortion behavior is completely different from the other two cases. In this case, the magnitude of vertical displacement at the middle of the weld line is higher than the vertical displacement of the first case with plate length of 100 mm, but it is less than the vertical displacement of the second case with plate length of 200 mm. Comparison of the displacement contours for the two cases with plate lengths of 100 and 300 mm shown in Figures 14 and 15 reveals that the plate with length of 300 mm experiences buckling distortion. This indicates that plate length affects distortion behavior and changes the mode of distortion. Increasing the weld length increases the magnitude of longitudinal contraction forces. Buckling occurs when the longitudinal contraction forces in areas away from the weld metal exceed the critical buckling load of the plate.

sec.p: In order to investigate the angular distortion behavior in plates 2 mm, a series of different cases with plate lengths of 100–350 mm and widths of 100–400 mm have been examined. The angular distortions at the weld start edge and middle of the weld line for the plates with width of 100 mm are shown in Figures 16 and 17. The results show that increasing the plate length increases angular distortions and vertical displacements.

sec.p: In order to have a better understanding of angular distortion behavior, the magnitude of angular distortions and vertical displacements at three sections of the plate, that is, weld start edge, middle of the weld line and weld stop edge, are summarized in Tables 3 and 4, respectively. Table 3 shows that the angular distortions at the middle of the weld line are lower than the angular distortions at the weld start and stop edges of the plate. The results also reveal that increasing the plate length increases the magnitude of angular distortions at the three sections. The results of vertical displacements presented in Table 4 show that the magnitude of vertical displacements at the middle of the weld line is higher than the vertical displacements at the weld start and stop edges of the plate. The results also reveal that increasing the plate length increases vertical displacements especially at the middle of the weld line in such a way that the difference between the magnitude of vertical displacements at the middle of the weld line and its corresponding values at the weld start and stop edges of the plate increases with the increase of plate length. For more details of the results of different cases, the interested reader can refer to the previous work of the present author.28

sec.p: In a similar manner, the results of angular distortions for the plates with widths of 200, 300 and 400 mm are shown in Figures 18–23. The results show that increasing the weld length increases angular distortions. This is because longer plates have larger volume of hot weld metal that gives rise to transverse contraction forces. Increasing transverse contraction forces increases consequently angular distortions. The results of different cases also reveal that increasing the plate length not only increases angular distortions but also results in nonlinear angular distortion behavior.

sec.title: Effect of plate width
sec.p: In order to investigate the effect of plate width (dimension perpendicular to the weld line) on angular distortions, a series of different cases with plate thicknesses of 1 and 2 mm, lengths of 100–350 mm and widths of 100–400 mm have been examined. The angular distortions at the weld start edge and middle of the weld line for plates 1 mm are shown in Figures 24 and 25, respectively. The results show that increasing the plate width in this range does not affect the magnitude of angular distortions considerably. The results also reveal that angular distortion behavior is nonlinear in all cases.

sec.p: The angular distortion results for plates 2 mm thick are shown in Figures 26–29. The results show that increasing the plate width decreases angular distortions and vertical displacements. This is because increasing the plate width increases the volume of cold base metal that gives additional stiffness to the structure, significantly reducing angular distortions.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, the effect of joint geometrical parameters, that is, thickness, length and width, on angular distortions in butt-welded plates has been investigated numerically and experimentally. According to the results of this study, the following conclusions are obtained.

list-item.p: Decreasing the plate thickness increases angular distortions and vertical displacements. Higher transverse contraction forces, lower stiffness and higher cooling rate in thin plates result in higher angular distortions in comparison to thick plates. The plate thickness also affects the angular distortion behavior. Linear angular distortions occur in plates 2 mm, whereas nonlinear angular distortions happen in plates 1.5 and 1 mm.

Increasing the plate length or weld length increases angular distortions. This is because plates with longer welds have larger volume of hot weld metal that gives rise to transverse contraction forces. Angular distortions increase as a consequence of increase of transverse contraction forces.
The plate length also affects the angular distortion behavior. Increasing the plate length (weld length) keeping the thickness and width constant results in nonlinear angular distortions.
Weld dimensions affect mode of distortions. Increasing the length of the plate in thin plates can lead to buckling distortion.

Angular distortions at the weld stop edge are higher than angular distortions at the weld start edge. Angular distortions at the middle of the weld line are smaller than the angular distortions at the weld start and stop edges of the plate. On the contrary, vertical displacements at the middle of the weld line are higher than the vertical displacements at the weld start and stop edges of the plate.

Increasing the plate width decreases angular distortions and vertical displacements. Increasing the plate width increases the volume of cold base metal resulting in additional stiffness. Increasing the stiffness results in lower angular distortions.

Plate dimensions (thickness, length and width) can affect the angular distortion behavior. Decreasing the plate thickness or increasing the plate length or width can result in nonlinear angular distortions.
